turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I was going to make you red zinger, but since Mars is the red planet, I went with peppermint.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Why do you even want to do this?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Actually, as part of the application, I was required to make a short video answering that very question. You want to see it?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Can’t you just tell me?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: But I made a video.

turns.speaker: video)
turns.transcript: I’m Dr. Sheldon Cooper, and I’d like to tell you why I should be chosen to go to Mars. I’m exceedingly smart. I graduated college at 14. While my brother was getting an STD I was getting a PhD. Penicillin can’t take this away. Being in close quarters, cleanliness is important and my hygiene is impeccable. In fact, animals don’t trust me because I smell like nothing. Literally nothing. During the seven-month space flight, I can keep up morale with my wacky sense of humour. Hey, Leonard, is there any peanut brittle left in that can?

turns.speaker: video)
turns.transcript: You mean this weirdly suspicious one?

turns.speaker: video)
turns.transcript: Yes. Open it and check.

turns.speaker: video)
turns.transcript: I don’t get it. There’s actually peanut brittle in… Please go to Mars.

turns.speaker: video)
turns.transcript: But on a more serious note, the most important reason I want to go to Mars is that I believe, as a scientist, it’s my duty to push the boundaries of human knowledge forward. Now, I know that life on Mars will be difficult. But life here on Earth is no picnic. Also, picnics are no picnic. Where should we go for lunch? Oh, I know, the ground. In conclusion, thank you for considering me for this journey of a lifetime. To Mars.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Afterwards, Leonard blew his nose, and pie came out.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It would be nice to have the increased income. Stop taking money from my parents.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Money from family does come with strings attached.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: You have no idea. They buy me a new BMW for my birthday but can I get seat warmers? No. Rajesh, if you want a warm butt, you’re gonna have to pay for it yourself. Well, maybe I will, old man.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I think that’s enough wine for now.

turns.speaker: Flowers
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, thank you. Delivery men are the unsung foot soldiers of our nation’s commerce. It’s because of people like you, people like me can limit our human contact. I’d shake your hand, but, well, you know.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: I’m not a delivery man, I’m a doctor. Although I do often deliver alarming biopsy results to my patients.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s humorous.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: All right.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yeah, I bet you leave your patients in stitches. That was also humorous.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: All right.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Are you bringing flowers to a patient to cushion the blow of a terminal diagnosis? That wasn’t a joke.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: All right. These are actually for a nice woman who makes sales calls to my office.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hmm. You know, they have delivery people that will do that for you.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: I was hoping to impress her by tracking her down on the Internet and then showing up unannounced at her door.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Making the extra effort. Good for you.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Great timing, food just got here.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Ooh, Siam Palace?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Uh, mee krob and chicken satay?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Uh, extra peanut sauce?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, but you can have mine.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Eh, well, very well. Oh, and on the topic of sharing things that are yours, there is a gentleman caller bringing flowers to your fiancée as we speak.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What? Why didn’t you say that first?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Why didn’t you get extra peanut sauce? We can both play this game.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Can I help you?

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: Oh, hi. Uh, does Penny live here?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: May I ask why?

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: Well, uh, I met her at my office, she winked at me. And, uh, I came hoping to initiate a romantic relationship.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay, um, look, I’m pretty sure she didn’t wink at you.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: Oh, she did. Seductively, like this. And then she touched my arm for two Mississippis. Like, you know, one Mississippi, two…

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I got it, I got it. Listen, um, I think there’s been a misunderstanding. See, Penny is my fiancée.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: Really? I’ve never seen her wear an engagement ring.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Really?

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: So, am I to presume that her flirtation was just a sales technique?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I think so.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: When will I learn? It’s just like the cute girl at the pet store all over again.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: Oh, uh, she touched my arm for five Mississippis, and I bought a two thousand dollar iguana habitat. Which she was always too busy to come over and see. You give these to Penny. You’re a, you’re a lucky man.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Thank you. Sorry.

turns.speaker: Man
turns.transcript: Oh, uh, you probably don’t want her to see this. It’s unnecessarily graphic.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hold on, Doctor. Leonard, where are your social skills? This man is clearly upset. We should invite him in for a hot beverage.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: He tried to score with Penny.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: So have these two, and they’re having dinner with us.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, this is a bad idea. We should go.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No. I’m the one that introduced him to her. I’ve got to say something.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Wow.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You’re engaged to my friend.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hey, Bernadette doesn’t mind where I get my motor running, as long as I park in the right garage.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I can’t believe you’re engaged to my friend. Oh, here she comes.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Smart. Whisper so the deaf chick can’t hear you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hi.

turns.speaker: (translating)
turns.transcript: Oh, hey, hi. Nice to see you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Um, can we talk to you about Raj?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: She says, sure, what about him?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, um, gosh, how do I start? Um, see, Raj is kind of naive. I mean, he hasn’t dated a whole lot of women. And I’m concerned that, without meaning to, you might be taking advantage of him. You know, by letting him buy you a bunch of expensive things.And I.. I… Howard, focus. Tell her what I’m saying.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Right. Are you a gold digger or not? Oh, uh, something, something, who the something do you think you are? Mind your own something business and go something yourself. Oh, wait, I got this now.

scene: Stuarts former bedroom in Howard and Bernadette’s house.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Boy, when was the last time Stuart cleaned this place?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No kidding. Oh, okay, I’m about to suck something up. What do you think this object sounds like?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Howie, I don’t want to play Lego, Toenail or Pill anymore. So, what do you think we should do with this room?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, I was thinking a home theatre or a gaming room, you know, like a man cave.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Why can’t it be a woman cave?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: As long as it has a home theatre, a video game system and you’re not allowed in it, you can call it whatever you want.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I’m being serious.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, what do you think we should do?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I don’t know, maybe a home office or, oh look. The teddy bear Stuart won the night we took him to the fair.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh. He was so excited.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah. You know, no matter how hard they tried, they could not guess his age.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I’ll give it to him next time I see him.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Have you heard from him since he left?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No. You’d think he would’ve called once he got settled in.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Hmm. Maybe he’s busy.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Too busy to call? He wasn’t too busy to binge-watch Hot in Cleveland with my Hulu password. What is happening? Are we missing him?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: No, that’s not what this feeling is. Is it?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Of course not. He drove us crazy. Like when you were gonna make that pie and Stuart ate all the blueberries.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: And he tried to deny it, but his teeth were all purple.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That was pretty cute.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah. Ew, we are missing him!

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That’s great, now they know where I live.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: What are you talking about? They’ve always known where you live.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah, if you want to go off the grid, you have to move out of your mother’s house.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Can we take a moment to discuss that I just lied to the government for you?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah. I would not have done that for you.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Howard, please just call the man, see what he wants.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: All right, all right.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hey, make sure you tell him that you weren’t home when he came by and that your Indian friend gave you the message the moment you stepped through the door.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yes, hello. Uh, this is Howard Wolowitz for Colonel Richard Williams.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, I take it back, don’t mention me.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hi, Colonel Williams, how can I help you? What? Oh, uh, yes, he is from India. No, I don’t know his immigration status. Relax, I’m still on hold. Speaking. Okay, sure, I can meet with you on Thursday. Caltech is fine. Yeah, and may I ask what this is about? I may not?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: That’s what he said to me.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You know, I like harp lessons, but I’m thinking of switching to elevator repair lessons. What are you working on?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I was thinking about your experiment on the neuroscience of decision making, and I realized, if we connect it to the measurement problem in quantum mechanics, we have a chance to disprove the role of consciousness in the Copenhagen Interpretation.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Wait, are you saying if we combine my experiment with your calculations, we can determine the precise moment in time when the wave function collapses?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It could be the most inspired combination since I mixed red Icee into my blue Icee. It was like drinking two sevenths of the rainbow.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon, this is really interesting.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yeah, and this one won’t stain my teeth purple.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You know, we’ve never collaborated professionally before. Are you worried it might affect our relationship?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That is a valid point. Perhaps we should establish some ground rules.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Well, that would make me feel better.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right, let’s start right now. Uh, rule number one, no using sexuality to get your way.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: That’s a ridiculous rule.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Is it?

scene: Howard and Bernadette’s apartment. Howard is on the phone to Raj.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, let me see the damage.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hang on.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, I think you broke the dowels. You’re not gonna have time to glue it back on, you’ll have to nail it.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: With what?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Does she have any pillows or wine glasses?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: She does.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Great. Neither of those. Try a hammer.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Did that feel good? You feel like a big man now?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: So I knocked down the bathroom door, picked up my poor unconscious mother, carried her to the car, and drove like a madman to the emergency room.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: You’re a real hero, Howard.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No, I did what any son would do.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hang on a second, you picked up your mother? Her own legs are barely able to do that.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I was filled with adrenaline. It happens to be how women lift cars off babies.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, I’m saying, it’d be easier to lift a car.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What can I tell you? After I found the courage to put her pants back on, I was unstoppable.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So, how is she?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: They’re running tests. I don’t know. It may have been a heart attack or heart-attack-like event.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What’s the difference?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: A heart-attack-like event is an event that’s like a heart attack.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Thanks for clearing that up.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Regardless, coronary problems are eminently treatable. What’s more likely going to kill Howard’s mother are the antibiotic-resistant super-bugs festering in every nook and cranny of this hospital.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, you’re not helping.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Disagree.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Go sit over there.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’ll sit over there, it looks cleaner.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Is there a history of heart disease in your family?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: My family is the history of heart disease. There’s a cave painting in France of one of my ancestors doing this (clutches chest).

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: So it’s probably genetic.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, maybe. Mom also had just gotten some news that might have upset her.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: It’s not important.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Come on, Howard, I’m going to be your wife. You can share anything with me.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You’d think that. But no.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: You told her we were going to get married and she had a heart attack?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You can’t take that personally.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: How else is she supposed to take it?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What you’ve got to keep in mind is that ever since my dad left, I’ve been the whole world to my mother. I mean, she’d be threatened by any woman who can give me what she can’t.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: You mean sexual intercourse?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, when you say it like that you make it sound creepy.

turns.speaker: (arriving)
turns.transcript: What happened?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Howard’s mother had a heart attack because I have sex with him and she can’t.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Bernie, wait!

turns.speaker: Raj)
turns.transcript: I’ll give you $1,000 if you’ll drive me home.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Hello, Mr. Rat Brain. Not so bitey without the rest of the rat to back us up now, are we?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Anybody home?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Hey, what brings you guys here?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Well, we were just on our way to lunch and wanted to see if you’d like to join.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Why? Because Sheldon’s not here this week, and you don’t think I have any other options? I’m just kidding. I’ll get my purse.

turns.speaker: Bert
turns.transcript: Hi, Amy. I, oh, I’m sorry. I didn’t know you had any company.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: That’s okay. Uh, Bert, this is Howard and Rajesh. Guys, this is Bert.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hi.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hey. Good to see you.

turns.speaker: Bert
turns.transcript: Anyway, I wanted to show you this tourmalinated quartzthat we got in the lab.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: This is so pretty. Bert works for the geology department.

turns.speaker: Bert
turns.transcript: Yeah. You know what, uh, geologists and Bon Jovi have in common?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You’re both into rock?

turns.speaker: Bert
turns.transcript: Yeah. Well, see ya.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, you forgot your quartz.

turns.speaker: Bert
turns.transcript: Oh, it’s okay. I want you to have it. Bye.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: He’s nice.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, he’s nice because he likes you.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: What?! No, he doesn’t.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: He brought you a pretty rock.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: So? He does that every day. Oh.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You know, if you’d rather skip lunch and hang out with your boyfriend Bert, it’s totally okay.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: He’s not my boyfriend.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Are you sure? He’s tall, pale and awkward. That sounds like your type.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Should someone as lonely as you really be making fun of me?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah, grow up, Howard. God.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: What do I do? I don’t want to hurt his feelings.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Maybe the problem is he thinks you’re available. Does he know you’re dating Sheldon?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I guess it hasn’t come up.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: There you go.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: And does Sheldon know you’re dating Sheldon?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I’m sorry. Who are you dating?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah, knock it off, Howard.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Hi.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hello.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m just contemplating Buridan’s donkey.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I understand. I’ll leave you be.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What, you’re familiar with the reference?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Of course. Jean Buridan proposed a philosophical thesis stating that a hungry donkey placed between two equidistant bales of hay would be paralysed by indecision and would starve to death.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Exactly.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Well, I wouldn’t want you to starve to death, so here’s an eggplant.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You know, some people believe that Buridan was plagiarizing Aristotle.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Really?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Although, in Aristotle’s example, he proposed an equally hungry and thirsty man caught between food and drink.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Huh. Yeah, I wonder if that’s related to the 12th century Persian philosopher, Al-Ghazali and his story of a man caught between two dates.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Are you suggesting Al-Ghazali was Aristotelian? ‘Cause if anything, he was anti-Aristotelian.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Al-Ghazali was anti-Aristotelian? Boy, you think you know a guy.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Sheldon, I’m surprised you’d choose to go to a pub.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: At our committee meeting, Amy made a motion for a picnic in a park, but I tacked so many amendments on that thing it sank like a lead balloon.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I then suggested a pub.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yeah, which I was initially sceptical of until I saw online that they serve Yorkshire pudding.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You don’t even like Yorkshire pudding.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, it’s yucky, but informing people about the history of Yorkshire is yummy, yum-yum.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: After a lively debate, that proposal passed by a two-zero margin.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Nice to see a busy couple keep the spark of bureaucracy alive.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Ignore them, Amy. They’re just jealous because they’ll never have a relationship as good as ours.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Isn’t this when he says bazooka or something?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I wasn’t making a joke, I was merely stating fact. Amy and I have a superior relationship to yours.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You don’t honestly think that, do you?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, I assumed you knew. The ranking of relationships in our circle by quality is me and Amy, Howard and Bernadette, Raj and his girlfriend, Penny and Chardonnay, Penny and you.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: There isn’t any ranking. And if there were, we wouldn’t be at the bottom of it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, and actually, I drink Sauvignon Blanc.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That’s the part you have a problem with?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Relax.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: There they go, fighting again. You’d never hear her talk that way to Sauvignon Blanc.

turns.speaker: Judge
turns.transcript: Pay the cashier. Sheldon Cooper?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Good morning, Your Honour. Dr. Sheldon Cooper appearing in pro se. That is to say, representing himself.

turns.speaker: Judge
turns.transcript: I know what it means. I went to law school.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And yet you wound up in traffic court. Anyway, if it would please the court, I’d like to begin with an opening statement.

turns.speaker: Judge
turns.transcript: The court would advise you to make it quick, as the court had a dicey-looking breakfast burrito this morning and just took an Imodium.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Very well, a quick opening statement. Like a milking stool, my case rests on three legs. I will demonstrate that I was improperly instructed in driving by a woman whose lack of respect for society borders on the sociopathic. I will argue that the emergency met the legal doctrine of quod est necessarium est licitum, that which is necessary is legal. But first, I will raise a Sixth Amendment issue. I’m unable to confront my accuser, a non-human entity, to wit, a camera. So, to sum up, improper instruction, quod est necessarium est licitum, Sixth Amendment. My milk stool is complete.

turns.speaker: Judge
turns.transcript: Impressive.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Judge
turns.transcript: Guilty. Pay the cashier.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I object. You’re completely ignoring the law.

turns.speaker: Judge
turns.transcript: No, I’m following the law. I’m ignoring you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Really? I would point out that I am at the top of my profession, while you preside over the kiddy table of yours.

turns.speaker: Judge
turns.transcript: Dr. Cooper, before I find you in contempt and throw you in jail, I’m going to give you a chance to apologize for that last remark.

turns.speaker: Sheldon

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No. No, no, no. You know what? The toilet’s been doing that. I called the building manager, so…

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, I can take a look at it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well…

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m quite familiar with plumbing. Not to brag, but I spent most of fifth grade with my head in a toilet.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, no, no, no. You know what, Sheldon, it’s okay. You don’t have to go into the bathroom.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s curious. If there’s no one here, why are there two glasses of wine on the table?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh. Well, you know, I, I’ve got two hands and a bit of a drinking problem.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Of course. Ask a silly question.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s odd.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Um, what?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: There are takeout containers in the trash can.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: So? That’s my dinner from last night.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What’s odd is they’re in the trash can.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay. Look, honey, I promise there’s no one’s here. I‘ve had a long day. I just want to have a quiet dinner by myself.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, very well. I’m no stranger to enjoying the pleasures of solitude. Oh!

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Have you gotten Leonard a welcome-home gift yet?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, great. Do you want to go halfsies on a two hundred dollar squirt gun?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, give me the flowers and pie.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: But if we show up and you’re holding them, she’ll think they’re only from you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: They are only from me. You said the gift of you was enough.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes, but now that I’ve seen what the gift of me with flowers and pie looks like, there’s no going back. Boy, I can’t wait to see the look on her face. We’re leaving right now.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What’s wrong?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Nothing.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What? Sheldon, tell me what’s going on.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I saw my mommy with a naked man and she was trying to be a mommy again.

turns.speaker: James
turns.transcript: You know, when I first read the script for Empire Strikes Back and Darth Vader told Luke he was his father, I thought for sure he was lying.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Me, too. But he wasn’t, was he?

turns.speaker: James
turns.transcript: He was not. How messed up was that?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: So messed up.

turns.speaker: James
turns.transcript: What do you say let’s go have some fun? My wife’s in New York, and I got a Lion King residual cheque burning a hole in my pocket.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey, what’s up?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I need a place to crash.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Uh, sure. Why?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Big fight with my mother.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Still arguing over which CSI is the best?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No, we agreed they all have their merits. This was about Bernadette.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What’s going on?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Howard’s gonna sleep here tonight. He had a fight with his mother.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Did you offer him a hot beverage?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, social protocol states when a friend is upset, you offer them a hot beverage, such as tea.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Tea does sound nice.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You heard the man, Leonard. And while you’re at it, I’m upset that we have an unannounced houseguest, so make me cocoa. Point of inquiry, given that Leonard is your secondary friend and Koothrappali is your primary friend, why didn’t you seek refuge under his roof?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: There’s no room. His sister is staying with him.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Wait, wait. What?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Cocoa, Leonard. Focus. I’m down in the dumps here.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Priya’s in town?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, some work thing. Anyway, my mother seems to think that Bernadette…

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hold on. When did Priya get here?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I don’t know. A couple of days ago. The thing is, Bernadette doesn’t like that I have to take care of my mother, and my mother doesn’t trust Bernadette.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, that’s a real pickle. Bye.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Don’t worry. As your tertiary friend, I am prepared to step in and comfort you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That’s not really necessary.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, no. I’ll finish making the tea, while you narcissistically ramble on about whatever’s troubling you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Thanks.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s what tertiary friends are for.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, I think I’ve narrowed it down to a faulty pin on the onboard communication chip.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Very impressive. You know, when you’re done with that, can you look at this? It doesn’t make smoke anymore.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: One toy at a time.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Mm. Sorry. Ah, maybe it’s for the best. I hear locomotive smoke is the second leading cause of death among train aficionados.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: What’s the first one?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Suicide.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Wrong. Obesity.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I have the tool you wanted.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: You guys don’t have to go to the trouble. I’m back in the money now, I can just buy another helicopter.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: It’s not about the money. It’s about solving a problem. It’s why I became an engineer. It’s what I like to do, it’s what I’m trained to do. It’s who I am.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, look at you, the little engineer that could.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Why don’t you just call tech support?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hey.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Whoa.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Not cool.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: There’s two kinds of people in this world, those who call tech support, and those who make fun of the people who call tech support.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I call tech support all the time.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Ha-ha.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You call tech support.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: What a baby.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hello.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, hey. You’re back. How was your trip?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It was wonderful.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Great. What did you do?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I made a new friend who likes trains as much as I do, uh, I kissed Amy on the lips, and, uh, the conductor played his banjo for me. Good night.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait, wait. I’m gonna need more details.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, well, my new friend’s name was Eric. Um, Amy lips tasted like the brownie we had for dessert. Oh, and the banjo-playing conductor was missing a finger, but he made up for it with his can-do attitude.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, hang on. Hang on. Are all those things equal to you?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hmm. It never occurred to me to pick a favourite.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, give it a go.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I can’t answer that without collecting additional data.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Additional data. You dog.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m not sure how listening to other nine-fingered banjo players makes me dog, but all right.

scene: A dance video game where the characters are imperial stormtroopers from Star Wars and Bobba Fett. Opens onto the apartment where Howard and Raj are dancing to the game.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Try to keep up, Howard, I’m killing it.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, I wish we looked as cool dancing in clubs as we do right now.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Don’t worry, this is exactly how you look when you’re dancing in clubs.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: You’re welcome, ladies.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Paradigm-shifting news, gentlemen. (Switches game off)

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Dude! I was about to Bollywood this bitch.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Earlier today, I invited Professor Stephen Hawking to join me in the popular online game Words with Friends. Moments ago, he accepted my request. Do you understand what that means?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That somewhere right now Stephen Hawking is saying, damn it, I meant to click no.”

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’ll walk you through it. The game is not called Words with Strangers. No, it’s not even called Words with Acquaintances. It is called Words with…

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’m not finishing your sentence. You pulled the plug on my funk.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Friends! It’s Words with Friends! Which Stephen Hawking and I officially are. Now all I need is a bunk bed with a slide, I’ll have everything I’ve ever wanted since I was six years old.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That’s really nice, Sheldon, I’m happy for you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And I’m happy for you, too. You are now friends with someone who is officially friends with Stephen Hawking. Enjoy it, boys. You may have peaked.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, I know Stephen Hawking. I worked with him.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And if they ever come out with a game called Words with People You Once Worked With, you’ll be off to the races.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, I don’t think this actually means…

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hold that thought! Professor Hawking has made a move. Boy, oh, boy. Oh, it’s only a matter of time before we’re coming up with fun nicknames for each other. I’ll be Coop. He’ll be Wheels. If he’s okay with that. (Leaves)

turns.speaker: shirt)
turns.transcript: All right. Crank up the AC, boys, it’s gonna get hot in here!

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I can’t believe you’re sore.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Hey, even professional pitchers need a rubdown after the game.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: But they throw an actual ball. You were throwing air at a TV.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: For your information, I also gave Leonard one hell of a high five.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I’m kind of surprised you agreed to do this in front of a stadium full of people.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: They’re doing Space Day and NASA asked me. I felt like I couldn’t say no.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Okay. Well, if you want, I could help you practice. I played a lot of softball growing up.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Thank you, that would be great.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Great. And while we’re at it, maybe we could butch up your run for when you head out to the mound.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: What’s wrong with the way I run?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: When was the last time you got a massage?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon walked on my back two weeks ago, but that was just ’cause there was a spider on his pillow and he was trying to get away.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Leonard stood on me once, too, but he was just trying to see the Rose Parade.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I don’t know the protocol, are you gonna be naked for your massage?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, yeah.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Hmm. Then this is probably too many clothes.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I came here to apologize.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay. Leonard, I really appreciate that, but I need a little time to myself.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay. I don’t get it, you said make an effort, here I am making an effort.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hello, Amy. It’s nice to see you.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Nice to see you, too.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And that’s how you make effort look effortless.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right. Can you please just go and we’ll talk about this tomorrow?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I don’t understand what you want.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I’m trying to figure it out.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You know what? If you’d like, I could whip up a quick relationship agreement. Well, I’m at a spa, I might as well do something relaxing.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon, why don’t we give them some privacy?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Very well. Hey, later we’ll check out the minibar, I’ll show you how Godzilla gets drunk.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: How about after this we go see the exotic bird show?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Not a good idea. My hair is a coveted nesting material.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Learning anything?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Well, sloth babies cling to their mothers’ bodies for almost a year. I’m going back to work after only four months, so I’ve learned I hate myself, I hate sloths, and I hate you for bringing me here.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Me I get, but that sloth is pretty cute.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: It’s not just the sloth. Polar bears nurse their cubs for almost eight months. The orangutan mother builds her baby a new home every night. And what do I do? I choose my career over my child.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Told you we should have gone to Legoland.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m sensing things have gotten awkward.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: No. It’s okay. If we’re friends, we should be able to talk about anything.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: So, you had some questions about me seeing other people.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Just a few.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: How many dates have you been on? Who were they with? Where’d you go? Where did you meet them? Did you sleep with them? And how much longer to the aquarium? I’m getting kind of hungry.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Let’s see. I have been on six dates with three different people. It was either for coffee or dinner. One I met at a bookstore and two I met online. I haven’t slept with anyone. The aquarium is 40 minutes away. And there’s a baggie of Cheerios for you in the glove compartment.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Is that regular or honey nut?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I mixed them.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You mixed them. No wonder gentleman callers are pounding down your door. Do you have any questions for me?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Just one. Are you doing okay?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I am.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Good. I want you to be happy.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I believe you. I’d believe you more if you threw a few Apple Jacks in here.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, thank you very much. Come back soon. With the other half of my tip. Hey, Sheldon, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: This is a restaurant. It’s lunchtime. I would think, as a waitress, you’d be familiar with the paradigm.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Is Leonard coming?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, I believe Leonard is waiting for you to come crawling back to him and apologize.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, that’s not gonna happen.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I assumed that would be your attitude. Hence, my true purpose in coming here.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Which is?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I want you to crawl back to him and apologize.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I’m busy.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Excuse me, miss. I’d like to order lunch.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Fine. What do you want?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I have a few questions. First, I notice that you offer soup and a half-sandwich?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Where exactly does the half-sandwich come from? Are you giving me half of someone else’s sandwich, or do I have to wait for someone else in the restaurant to order the other half?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, no, Sheldon, they just make a half-sandwich.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You can’t make a half-sandwich. If it’s not half of a whole sandwich, it’s just a small sandwich.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, fine, it’s soup and a small sandwich. Is that what you want?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Of course not. I’ll have my usual.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Great.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Aren’t you going to ask me if I want a beverage?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Don’t you usually get lemonade?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Do you want lemonade?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Anything else?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes, I want you to apologize to Leonard.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I am not going to apologize. I’ve done nothing wrong. He is completely overreacting.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Irrelevant. The disruption in your relationship is making my life intolerable.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, I’m sorry, Sheldon, but this really isn’t about you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I don’t follow.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, yeah, I’ll be right there. Look, Sheldon, I have to go.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right, let’s assume, ad argumentum, that in this case, Leonard is wrong.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Leonard is wrong.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Considering the number of transgressions you’ve committed that he’s overlooked, don’t you think that, just this once, you could return the favour?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I’m coming. Goodbye, Sheldon. What do you mean, transgressions I’ve committed?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Were you under the impression that Leonard has no complaints about you?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Like what? Yeah, yeah, I see you, you’re making a little cheque sign in the air, I got it, just hold your horses. What does Leonard complain about?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Your driving, the plethora of stuffed animals on your bed that stare at him during your amorous activities, your constant tardiness, your singing.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: My singing?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s actually from my list, but Leonard would be a fool if he didn’t agree with it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, if Leonard has so many problems with me, why hasn’t he just said so?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Because, according to him, you’re oversensitive and have a temper.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, really? Well, then, do me a favour and tell Leonard that he can drop dead!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And she wonders why she’s constantly undertipped.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right, Ms. Jenson. Uh, before we begin, may I offer you a refreshment? Water, coffee, tea, a marijuana cigarette?

turns.speaker: Jenson
turns.transcript: No, thanks. I’m fine.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Now, are you sure? Everyone’s smoking them. I think they’re the best.

turns.speaker: Jenson
turns.transcript: I don’t do drugs.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Excellent, yeah. That was a ruse. They’re not the best. Physics is the best. And by the way, coffee was also an unacceptable choice. All right, so I see here you’re from Des Moines, Iowa. Uh, you’re summa cum laude in theoretical physics from Stanford University. Oh, and two years ago, you had a persistent ear infection. I hope that didn’t cause any hearing loss.

turns.speaker: Jenson
turns.transcript: No, of course not. How did you know about that?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I did a comprehensive background check. Medical records, credit reports, criminal history. (Hiding mouth behind book)  I trust you paid off those parking tickets.

turns.speaker: Jenson
turns.transcript: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hearing unimpaired, good.

turns.speaker: Jenson
turns.transcript: Look, Dr. Cooper, I really want this position. It would be an incredible honour to work for a man of your brilliance.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Flattery will not get you this job, Ms. Jenson.

turns.speaker: Jenson
turns.transcript: It’s not flattery if it’s the truth.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, well, thank you. Welcome aboard.

scene: Howard’s bedroom. Howard enters in a silk dressing gown, puts on romantic music and sets up mood lighting. Gets onto bed.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: So, my dear, we meet again.

turns.speaker: Sackhoff
turns.transcript: Hello, Howard. I’ve missed you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I’ve missed you, Katee Sackhoff.

turns.speaker: Sackhoff
turns.transcript: One question.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Anything.

turns.speaker: Sackhoff
turns.transcript: Why am I wearing my Battlestar Galactica flight suit in bed?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Why are you in bed with me? If we start to question this, it all falls apart.

turns.speaker: Sackhoff
turns.transcript: Sorry. Oh, ravish me, Howard. My loins ache for you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, if you insist.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: Howard, have you seen my girdle?!

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No, Ma!

turns.speaker: Wolowitz
turns.transcript: I can’t find it, and I’m late for my Weight Watchers meeting!

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Maybe it committed suicide! Leave me alone! Now, where were we?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I believe you were about to rip off my uniform with your teeth.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Bernadette? What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: Sackhoff
turns.transcript: Well, if I had to guess, I’d say I’m here because you saw me earlier this evening, and you’re still hung up on me.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No, I’m not.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Clearly you are. Otherwise, based on past experience, we’d be done by now.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Okay, I’m a little confused here.

turns.speaker: Takei
turns.transcript: Oh, my. Can I help?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Not that kind of confused.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: What’s George Takei doing here?

turns.speaker: Sackhoff
turns.transcript: Howard, do you have latent homosexual tendencies?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No, of course not.

turns.speaker: Takei
turns.transcript: So you say. Yet, here I am.

turns.speaker: Sackhoff
