turns.transcript: Oh, and there’s something else I wanted to ask you. Why did you spend a month’s rent on a toy helicopter?!

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, you’re where that bill goes.

turns.speaker: Koothrapalli
turns.transcript: I’m tired of indulging your foolish lifestyle. It’s time you learned responsibility. And the only way to teach you that is to cut off your allowance.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: No, Daddy, no. There are lots of other ways to teach me responsibility. I know, you can give me an egg and make me take care of it for a week.

turns.speaker: Koothrapalli
turns.transcript: No, my mind is made up. Starting now, you’re on your own.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: But, Daddy, I, I miss my family so much, and with you and Mummy getting a divorce, I feel sad and empty. Buying a little toy every now and then helps me fill that void. So while I can’t hug you every day, flying that helicopter…

turns.speaker: Koothrapalli
turns.transcript: I’m cutting you off.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Just to be clear, financially or mid-sentence?

turns.speaker: (singing)
turns.transcript: Are we an item? Girl, quit playin’.

turns.speaker: (singing)
turns.transcript: We’re just friends, what are you sayin’?

turns.speaker: (singing)
turns.transcript: Say there’s another and look right in my eyes.

turns.speaker: (singing)
turns.transcript: My first love broke my heart for the first time.

turns.speaker: Together
turns.transcript: And I was like, baby, baby, baby, ooh, like, baby, baby, baby, no, like, baby, baby, baby, ooh, I thought you’d always be mine.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: So I read a study that says a man with a dog is three times more likely to get a woman’s phone number.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Is it true even when the man lets his dog lick peanut butter off his tongue?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I don’t see why not.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: If you’re really desperate to meet women and like having food eaten out of your mouth, I could set you up with my mom.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Why is that funny? That’s just unhygienic.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It’s a joke.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I don’t think so. I believe that a joke is a brief oral narrative with a climactic humorous twist. For example, uh, Wolowitz’s mother is so fat that she decided to go on a diet, or exercise, or both. See? The twist is that people don’t usually change. Well, they don’t.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey, guys, don’t forget, my episode’s on TV tomorrow night.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: We’ll be there.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Can we bring anything?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, that’s so sweet of you, but I was gonna steal food from here. You know, my treat.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Wait, if Howard’s mother is coming, then you should also steal marbles. Because she’s obese, and hippos are obese, and in the popular board game Hungry Hungry Hippos, they eat marbles. Maybe I need to dumb these down for you.

scene: The hallway. Raj is ejected from the apartment.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I really thought she would say it.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: As if Valentine’s Day wasn’t bad enough, you try to kill my dog? And with cheap chocolate, no less?

turns.transcript: Yeah, we weren’t even out of the room that long.

turns.transcript: Oh, no, come on. It was a while. It was a while.

turns.speaker: Vet

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: All right. Uh, would, would it be okay for me to see her? We’re usually in bed by now, and I want her to know that I’m here. Yes, we sleep together, and sometimes we spoon.

turns.transcript: It’s okay. I sleep with my dog, too. We’re not supposed to let people in back, but I think I can make an exception.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Vet
turns.transcript: Come on. By the way, I sang her Katy Perry.

turns.transcript: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: Vet
turns.transcript: And I don’t care what that obnoxious parrot back there says. I crushed it.

turns.transcript: I think there’s something going on between the two of them.

turns.transcript: Maybe, but you also think nine minutes isn’t a while, so what do you know?

turns.transcript: You could have offered me a ride home.

turns.transcript: You’re lucky I didn’t run you over.

turns.speaker: Sheldon

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You’re right, I’m the problem, I’m the one that needs help.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well that’s not much of an apology, but I’ll take it.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Excuse me. Is there anything you’d like to apologise for?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes. I’m sorry I tried to blow up your head. It was uncalled for.

turns.speaker: Raj)
turns.transcript: You won’t believe this.

turns.transcript: Forget your suit, look at my arms waving, I’m like a flamingo on Ritalin.

turns.transcript: How about your follicle-stimulating hormone levels?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon, I am not going through menopause.

turns.transcript: Are you sure? You said that with the testy bark of an old biddy.

turns.transcript: Let’s look at this logically. I have a stomach, I get hungry. I have genitals, I have the potential for sexual arousal.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: A cross we all must bear. You know, in difficult moments like this, I often turn to a force greater than myself.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Religion?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Star Trek. Did you see Star Trek: The Motion Picture?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Don’t. It’s terrible. However, in it, we learn that when Spock finds himself drawn off the path of logic by feelings bubbling up from his human half, he suppresses them using the Vulcan mental discipline of Kolinar.

turns.transcript: Are you suggesting we live our lives guided by the philosophies found in cheap science fiction?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Cheap science fiction?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Using Kolinar to suppress my anger at that last comment.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Is it possible that your concern for me at this moment is motivated by nothing more than simple jealousy?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I hadn’t considered that. Give me a moment. All right, I’ve considered it.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: And?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I reject it.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You reject it because you don’t feel jealousy, or because you are suppressing jealousy?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I think I’ll eat my lunch at home.

turns.transcript: That’s not your lunch, Sheldon, those are the cadaver brain specimens.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh. As they were incorrectly sliced, you can see how I could mistake them for my sashimi.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: So, other than you taking your relationship to the next level with another guy, this was nice.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Yes, well, thanks for seeing me to my door.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Oh, you’re welcome.

turns.speaker: (inside)
turns.transcript: (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. (Knock, knock, knock) Amy. Let’s wrap things up out there.

turns.transcript: Um, good night, Stuart.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Good night.

turns.transcript: How did you get into my apartment?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Wow. Is that the kind of nagging I can expect now that you’re my girlfriend? Good thing I drew this up.

turns.transcript: What’s that?

turns.transcript: I present to you the relationship agreement. A binding covenant that, in its 31 pages, enumerates, iterates and codifies the rights and responsibilities of Sheldon Lee Cooper, here and after known as the boyfriend, and Amy Farrah Fowler, here and after known as the girlfriend.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: It’s so romantic.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Mutual indemnification always is. Why don’t you start perusing while I set up my notary stamp.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Section 5: Hand-holding. Hand-holding is only allowed under the following circumstances. A: Either party is in danger of falling off a cliff, precipice or ledge. B: Either party is deserving of a hearty handshake after winning a Nobel Prize. C: Moral support during flu shots. Seems a bit restrictive.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Feel free to retain a lawyer.

turns.transcript: This is delightful.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: Sheldon-bot
turns.transcript: It’s much easier to enjoy the picturesque route we travel to work when you remove the spectre of fiery vehicular death.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Refresh my memory. Why didn’t I just put you in the trunk?

turns.speaker: Sheldon-bot
turns.transcript: Because I called shotgun. Remember?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Right.

turns.speaker: Sheldon-bot
turns.transcript: You seem tense. Perhaps this will relax you.

turns.transcript: I don’t want to listen to music, Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Sheldon-bot
turns.transcript: Very well. I don’t understand why you’re not enjoying this. Together, in this car, with my enhanced capabilities, we’re like Knight Rider.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Except in Knight Rider, the car isn’t a yammering sphincter.

turns.speaker: Sheldon-bot
turns.transcript: You mock the sphincter, but the sphincter is a class of muscle without which human beings couldn’t survive. There are over 50 different sphincters in the human body. How many can you name?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I was wrong, this is exactly like Knight Rider.

turns.speaker: Sheldon-bot
turns.transcript: Perhaps you’d be interested in a different game.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Sheldon-bot
turns.transcript: This is a photograph of the 1911 Solvay Conference on the theory of radiation and quanta. Using Photoshop, I’ve introduced a few anachronisms. See if you can spot all 24. I’ll give you the first one. Madame Curie should not be wearing a digital watch. And go.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That’s it. Bye-bye. (Turns off screen.)

turns.speaker: on)
turns.transcript: Bazinga.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Whoa!

turns.transcript: I have an override switch.

turns.transcript: I almost died!

turns.transcript: I’m still going to go with you.

turns.transcript: How many times do I have to say I’m sorry?

turns.transcript: Hmm. You two got married.

turns.speaker: Amy

turns.speaker: Sheldon

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Bernadette got her doctorate.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, Howard and I are working with the government on our quantum gyroscope.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: We’ve all come a long way. There’s a lot to be proud of.

turns.transcript: For God’s sake, just drive in the knife, why don’t you.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: What’s your problem?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Well, you’re all thinking it, I’m the only one who hasn’t done anything worthwhile.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I was not thinking it. Although, now that you point it out, it is undeniable.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Raj, if it’s any consolation, I’m no better off than I was ten years ago.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, yay, I have a doctorate in astrophysics and I’m every bit as awesome as the pasty-faced owner of a comic book store.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Raj, show some compassion. Those are things that we think but don’t say.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Excuse me.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sorry, Stuart.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Hey, I’m in a hospital and I’m not the patient. I’m fine.

turns.transcript: Mustache is looking good there, Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Sheldon

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Because it’s working. In the past few weeks, unburdened by trivial decisions, I’ve co-authored two papers in notable peer-reviewed journals, and I’m close to figuring out why the Large Hadron Collider has yet to isolate the Higgs boson particle.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You left out, got chafed testicles because you no longer wear underpants.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Wow, can’t believe he has a girlfriend.

turns.speaker: dice)

turns.transcript: Here’s some other fun news on the Raj/Emily front. He gave her a pair of diamond earrings and leased her a car.

turns.transcript: You’re kidding.

turns.speaker: Penny

turns.transcript: We’ll find somebody else.

turns.transcript: Yeah. You know, I bet you and I have more in common than we think.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Such as?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I don’t know. Tell me some things you like.

turns.speaker: Amy

turns.transcript: Hey, how about some music?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Great. Sheldon never lets me listen to music in the car. He doesn’t want to be mistaken for a gang member.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Find something you like.

turns.speaker: Amy

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: and then the next day was 73 degrees, and the day after that was 72, and then it was 72 again, uh, then it was 74, and that brings us to today, at I’d wear shorts if I had a pair. 78.

turns.transcript: Sheldon. We’ve known each other a long time. We are perfectly capable of having a conversation without relying on a list off the Internet.

turns.speaker: Amy

turns.transcript: Very well. I know you’ve been seeing other men. Have you had coitus with any of them?

turns.transcript: Man, I walked right into that one.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Hey, Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What happened?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: I was cooking in the back room last night and the hot plate caught on fire.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And you couldn’t put it out?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: I was across the street at the do-it-yourself car wash, taking a shower.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: So when will you reopen?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Um, I don’t know. I’m waiting to hear back from the insurance company.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: So, tomorrow?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: I don’t mean to be rude, Sheldon, but, uh, my life is kind of falling apart right now.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Your life? The university is making me do string theory and my girlfriend loves me so much she wants to live with me. And now, the place I need to go when I’m sad is damp and smells funny.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Well, sorry I let you down.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No. I do not accept this. Everything is changing and I hate it. It stops now. I’m helping you get back on your feet. I would like to purchase this comic book, please.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: That’ll be $2.99.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Really? It’s soaking wet.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: Fine, a dollar.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Can you break a twenty?

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: No, I only have hundreds.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You know what? I don’t always recognize sarcasm, but I do right now, and I don’t appreciate it. I’m sorry for your loss. But you’re not the only one whose day has been a disaster.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: (Light falls on ground just where he was standing a moment before) That could have killed me. I can’t catch a break.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Go away, Sheldon.

turns.transcript: It’s Leonard.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh. Go away, Leonard.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s open.

turns.transcript: Hey.

turns.transcript: I’m not going to that party, Leonard.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay, listen. You don’t have to wear the wig. At this party, we’re gonna win first prize just by showing up with a girl.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s not the wig.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Did I do something? I mean, I tried to be friends with Zack, like you said, which believe me, was difficult, given how you and me used to be, you know, you and me, and now you and him are you and him.

turns.transcript: Then what are you?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I don’t know. I only started seeing Zack again so I wouldn’t be alone on New Year’s Eve. How pathetic is that?

turns.transcript: Not as pathetic as dressing up like this and going to a comic book store on New Year’s Eve.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You make a cute Green Arrow.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Green Lantern.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Like there’s a difference.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: There’s a big difference. Arrow. Lantern.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Whatever. Look, if Zack and I had just gone to a regular club or a party, it would have been fine, but this, with the costumes, and you.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What about me?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Nothing. Let’s go to the party. (Puts on wig) How do I look?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Um, I guarantee you’ll be the prettiest girl there.

turns.speaker: door)

turns.transcript: Oh.

turns.transcript: Aw, damn.

turns.speaker: (singing)
turns.transcript: Ooh, baby, baby, baby, baby. Ooh, baby, baby, baby, baby.

turns.transcript: Ah, push it.

turns.transcript: Here’s Spock’s head with no body. Here’s Mr. T’s body with no head. Oh, yeah, here’s Spock’s body with Mr. T’s head. I pity the fool who’s illogical.

turns.speaker: Penny

turns.transcript: Huh? That’ll come off.

turns.transcript: You see what you’re doing? Stop that.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Fascinating.

turns.transcript: What?

turns.transcript: It appears to be a Lord of the Rings ring.

turns.transcript: Oh.

turns.transcript: It’s even got the Elvish engraving on it.

turns.transcript: It’s not Elvish. It’s the language of Mordor written in Elvish script. One Ring to

scene: The apartment. Sheldon and Leonard are playing three dimensional chess.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Bishop to queen four, level two. Check.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, knight takes bishop. You all right?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m fine.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Are you? You left your queen exposed from above, you trapped your knight in the corner, and you keep sighing and saying, why me?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Very well. Can I ask you a question about women?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: We got you that book last year. Wasn’t everything in there?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No, I’m having a relationship problem with Amy. And by the way, that book gave me nightmares.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, if it makes you feel any better, I screwed things up pretty good with Penny.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Look at us, Leonard, engaging in the social convention of men bellyaching about their ol’ ladies.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I guess we are. So, what’s going on?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Believe it or not, Amy has embarked on a campaign to increase my feelings for her by making me happy.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, that must be very difficult for you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s awful. This morning, she arranged for me to be an Amtrak junior conductor for the day. It, it’s usually only open to children. She got them to make an exception.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Shame on her.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: They let me blow the whistle, Leonard.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: She’s good.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I know. And it gets worse. Her efforts are causing me to have affectionate feelings for her at inappropriate times.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You mean, like in bed or in the shower?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No! Would you please stop referencing that infernal book? For example, this morning, I was calculating the random motion of virtual particles in a vacuum, when suddenly the particles morphed into an image of Amy’s dandruff gently cascading down onto her pale, slightly hunched shoulders. Oh, what has that vixen done to me, Leonard? And how do I make it stop?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, if you had a physical relationship, I’d say propose during sex. Turns out that’s a real mood killer.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I assume we’re talking about you now?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: So, that’s how this works? I complain, and then you complain, and no one offers any solutions?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Pretty much.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, no wonder the women are winning.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s so cute and rustic up here.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I know. Did you see they still have a video rental place? it’s like Colonial Williamsburg.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, cell service is down to one bar, so if anyone needs medical attention or to tell a stranger their political views are stupid, now’s the time.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Have you ever been off the grid before?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Once. The battery ran out on my phone. I had to wait for my iPad to turn on.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I was afraid he was gonna eat me.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Three thousand hours. Three thousand hours clicking on that mouse, collecting weapons and gold. It’s almost as if it was a huge waste of time.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Whoever did this knew what they were doing. He got in and out of your account in under 15 minutes, transferred all your stuff, and didn’t leave a digital fingerprint.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh! There isn’t enough camomile tea in the world to quell the rage in my heart.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hold on. I’m talking to an orc under the bridge in Thunder Bluff who says if we pay him, he’ll help us track down your things.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Can we trust him?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I should say so, he appears to be a member of the Nigerian royal family.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Whoa! Somebody’s auctioning off a jewelled ostrich bridle!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No. Glenn’s was leather. He was a simple ostrich. Is! Is, I haven’t given up hope.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey, Penny. We’re kind of in the middle of a crisis, here.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, I know. Bernadette told me. Sorry, Sheldon. I know that game meant a lot to you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That game? Excuse me, Penny, but Doodle Jump is a game. Angry Birds is a game. World of Warcraft is a massively multi-player online role-playing… all right, technically it’s a game.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Bad news, the Nigerian prince may be a fraud.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, well, anyways, I brought you a day-old cheesecake to cheer you up!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Stale pastry is hollow succour to a man who is bereft of ostrich.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Just say thank you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I thought I just did.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right. See you later.

turns.speaker: Priya
turns.transcript: Oh! Hello.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, hi! I was just dropping off a cheesecake to Sheldon. He was robbed of a bunch of imaginary crap that’s useful in a make-believe place.

turns.speaker: Priya
turns.transcript: I don’t know what that means.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, well, sadly, I do.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry. I did, I crossed a line. I didn’t mean to!

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Who says something like that right in the middle of sex?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I don’t know, it just came out. People say weird things during sex all the time.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, well, they sure as hell don’t say that.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It was the heat of the moment.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, the heat of the moment is, ooh, yeah, just like that, not will you marry me?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry. Just, just give me another chance.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Why, so you can crawl under the covers and go, hey, baby, want to go look for houses in neighbourhoods with good schools?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Again, I’m sorry. You know, with Howard and Bernadette getting married, I got caught up in a little wedding fever. I take it back.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You can’t take something like that back. I mean, what are we even supposed to do now?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay, at some point, we’ll look back and this is going to be a funny story. Why don’t we just start doing that now?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You’re kidding.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No. Hey, do you remember that time when I proposed to you in bed? And you were all, like, what are you doing? That was so funny. So funny.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: It’s not funny.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Give it a minute. Is that a little smile I see there? I should go.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Gentlemen, the most interesting thing just happened with this spoon.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Unless it was singing Be Our Guest, I doubt it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yeah, I picked it up without thinking about it. Which raises a neuroscientific question, when did I decide to pick it up?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: The bigger question is, what are you gonna eat with that spoon? You didn’t get any food.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: He does raise an interesting point.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Amy is studying the time lag between intent and awareness, and I realized that applies to the measurement problem in quantum mechanics. Now, I recognize there will be a time lag between me saying that and you Googling what it means, so I’ll wait.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I understand it, Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah, me, too.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, I spaced. Are we still talking about the spoon?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It’s nice to see you taking an interest in Amy’s work.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, don’t get me wrong. Neurobiology’s nothing more than the science of gray squishy stuff. But, you know, when it connects to physics, gas up the Ford, Martha, we’re going for a drive.

turns.speaker: television
turns.transcript: Parsa doesn’t have those kind of resources.

turns.speaker: voice
turns.transcript: No, and that’s why he had Erin Pace rewire it…

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m so proud of you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: We haven’t even gotten to my scene yet.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I know, but you’re going to be a TV star and you haven’t left me yet. That takes guts.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I don’t know about you, but I’m very uncomfortable with all this.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Why?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’ve never seen this show before and now I’m starting with episode 246? It’s unnatural.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Just think of the first 245 as the prequel.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: All right.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, shh, guys, guys, this is it.

turns.speaker: TV
turns.transcript: I guess it’s you and me, kid.

turns.speaker: TV
turns.transcript: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: TV
turns.transcript: I’m trying to make peace.

turns.speaker: TV
turns.transcript: We’re good.

turns.speaker: TV
turns.transcript: Good.

turns.speaker: TV
turns.transcript: Really? Because…

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Are you kidding me?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What’s wrong?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, the diner scene. Where’s my diner scene?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, don’t ask me. Until I see the prequel, I’m lost.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: No, there was supposed to be a big scene with me and Mark Harmon, but it’s gone.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: What happened?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: They must’ve cut it.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, Penny, I’m, I’m sorry.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That stinks.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’m sure you were great.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: This doesn’t make any sense. I mean, I, I thought I did a, a really good job, I… Excuse me.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’ve been studying how to make people laugh. They say that comedy is tragedy plus time. Let’s tickle some ribs.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I wonder how much she spent on this.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Ooh, let’s find out.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It doesn’t matter. It’s the thought that counts.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, yeah, and beauty’s on the inside, size doesn’t matter, how much she spend?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Seriously, guys, I don’t want to know.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, my.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, come on, you can’t say oh my, and then not tell me.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: These things go for five hundred dollars and up.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Damn. All I got for Valentine’s Day was a postcard saying my Vermont Teddy Bear was back-ordered.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, so, she drops off a five hundred dollar gift and she’s not trying to get back together with you?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Maybe you’re right.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Or she’s telling the truth and just being nice.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Maybe you’re right. Wow, I am easy to manipulate. (Phone rings) Oh, guys, it’s Emily. What should I do?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, answer it. Just be strong. And if she starts to cry, don’t make any promises. And most importantly, put it on speaker so we can hear.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hello?

turns.speaker: (voice)
turns.transcript: Hey, it’s Emily. Is this a good time?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah, yeah. Sure. What’s up?

turns.speaker: Emily
turns.transcript: Was it okay I left that gift? I’m really hoping we can be friends.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Maybe, maybe.

turns.speaker: Emily
turns.transcript: Um, you think you’d want to grab a cup of coffee? Hello?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, I seem to be taking an annoying amount of time deciding how I feel about this.

turns.speaker: Emily
turns.transcript: I just, I miss hanging out with you. It’s not like I lost a friend, it’s like I lost my best friend. Is there any chance you’d want to come over?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, I don’t think that’s a good idea.

turns.speaker: Emily
turns.transcript: Okay. I’m just, I’m having a really hard time, but that’s not your problem, that’s mine. I, I won’t bother you again, but please know that you’ll always have a place in my heart. Bye, Raj. You’re a good guy.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Good-bye, Emily. That was rough, you guys.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I know, but you did it. I’m so proud of you.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Well, anyway, I’ll leave you to your girls’ night.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Are you sure you don’t want to stay here with us?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: No, I kind of feel like being alone right now.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Well, if you change your mind, we’ll be here.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Thank you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Say hi to Emily for us.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Will do.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, hey. Haven’t heard from you in a couple days. You still mad at me?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Nope. I have no reason to… “B” mad at you. Minus.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Wow.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: That’s right. On my paper. Not yours, mine, you punk-ass elf.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I don’t know what to say.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hmm, how about, gee, Penny, you’re smarter than I thought. You may be the one in school, but I’m the one who learned a lesson. I’m so stupid, Penny. Duh.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: She sounds exactly like you.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay, so we know that previous attempts to send a message into space, like the Golden Record on Voyager, were heavily criticized.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, aliens could only play the Golden Record if they figured out how to build a record player.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Eh. Although, to be fair, I watched E.T. build a telephone out of a Speak & Spell and an umbrella. Dude was like a little brown MacGyver.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That would be more helpful if E.T. were real.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Well, my feelings were real when he was about to die.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: My God, when he’s on the table and they use the paddles on him.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: And he’s all white.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: They zip him up in that bag.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: And Gertie can’t stop crying.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: The flower dies.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay, let’s talk about something else.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: All right, so it sounds like we need a way to communicate that’s simple.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: And doesn’t require outside machinery to be built to access it.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It’s also a problem because we don’t even know if the aliens who find this can see. I mean, they might communicate in a totally different way than us.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Like when my dog is mad at me, she tells me by peeing in my slippers.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That’s actually a valid example. Animals do deliver messages through scent.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Bees talk to each other by dancing. Whales have their songs.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah. Penny has about twenty different ways of rolling her eyes that each mean something different.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay, so, what it sounds like is, what we want is a device that can deliver a message through not only sight, but other senses, as well.

Anyway, there’s new studies that show, people in comas are aware of everything going on around them.
