turns.transcript: Oh, hey guys.

turns.speaker: Sheldon)
turns.transcript: Uh, hi Penny. (Raj and Howard are heard to scream as the time machine slides back down the stairs.) Take a break, guys!

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, just, you know, moving a… time machine.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, okay, neat, but I really got to get to work, so….

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No problem. (Removes glasses, pulls down out of order tape from lift doors, and forces them open.) Hang on. (Takes Penny in his arms as he holds onto the lift cable.)

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: But, what about your time machine.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Some things are more important than toys. (She puts her arms around his neck as he dangles from the cable.)

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, I’m scared.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Don’t worry baby, I’ve got you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, Leonard. (Kisses him as they descend from view. Leonard wakes up still sitting in the time machine.)

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s still my turn.

scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. Sheldon writhes in bed, then wakes up on an alien planet.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh dear. Two suns and no sunscreen.

turns.speaker: Spock
turns.transcript: Hello again, Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What is it now, tiny Spock?

turns.speaker: Spock
turns.transcript: I am very disappointed in you. You broke your toy and switched it with Leonard’s. You should be ashamed of yourself.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You’re the one who told me to play with it.

turns.speaker: Spock
turns.transcript: If I told you to jump off the bridge of the Enterprise, would you do it?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: No. If I got on the bridge of the Enterprise, I would never, ever leave.

turns.speaker: Spock
turns.transcript: Trust me, it gets old after a while. You must right your wrong, Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Why? I got away with it. Leonard has his toy, and he’s never going to open it, so he won’t know it’s broken. And I have a toy that isn’t broken. Everybody’s happy.

turns.speaker: Spock
turns.transcript: Well I am unhappy.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I thought where you come from they don’t have emotions.

turns.speaker: Spock
turns.transcript: I come from a factory in Taiwan. Now do the right thing.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You know what you are? Well, you’re a green blooded buzzkill. Perhaps it’s time you beam on out of here.

turns.speaker: Spock
turns.transcript: Fine. I will just use the transporter. Oh, right. You broke it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Very well. Cooper to Enterprise, one to beam up. Energise. (Throws Spock away. Get’s attacked by a Gorn. Wakes up.) Ah. Tiny Spock. Help.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hey, did I say something to upset you?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No, I’m fine.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Really? Because usually we walk side by side, and I just went up two flights of stairs staring at your bottom.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Just drop it.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay, I think I see what’s happening here. You’re jealous of me.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh, please. What could you possibly have that I would be jealous of?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It’s not what I have, it’s how many people I’m having it with.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Come on, Sheldon, we’ll watch Game of Thrones over here.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Gladly.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, good, go. You know, it’ll be nice to watch an episode without someone saying, I read the books, don’t get too fond of this character.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s not always because they die. In one case, it’s because they’ve become involved with underground tree people from the dawn of time. Yeah, but I won’t say who it is. It’s Brann.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Wait, what is going on?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Leonard’s being a jerk, so we’re gonna watch over here.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Do you guys want to watch with us?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: As long as I don’t have to watch with him.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Fine, I don’t want to watch with you either. I’ll go over here.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Why do you get to pick?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay, then you go there.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Don’t tell me where to go.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Howard, just come in here.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, come on, Raj.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Wait, did Amy make her spinach dip?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: She did.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: And I’m gonna eat it all.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I really like my saber-toothed cat. Thank you.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: My pleasure. Maybe after lunch, we can go to Marie Callender’s and have some pie.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’d like that. This is turning out to be a perfect Saturday.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Good. I’m glad. Oh, man. Did you see the way she smiled at me?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Fine. Go ahead.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No. This is our day.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: If you want to chase after her, chase after her.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Ah, who am I kidding? I wouldn’t have a shot with a girl like that.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Don’t put yourself down. You’re a very attractive man.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You think so?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah. Absolutely. It wouldn’t kill you to take a Pilates class with me now and then, but you have a certain wiry appeal.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, well, it doesn’t matter ‘cause she wasn’t really smiling at me.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Actually, in this case, I think she was.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Really?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Bye.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: What a douche.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, look. It’s Sheldon and little Leonard. Hi, little Leonard.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hi, Amy.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Hey, Cuddles.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Cuddles?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes, Cuddles. We cuddled. Grow up, Leonard.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Amy, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Well, I came here to get a bottle of wine like Penny taught me to do when you’re sad.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, but why didn’t you go back to your apartment?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Didn’t you go to high school, Leonard? Parking lots are where all the cool kids hang out. Not that the rat bastards ever invited me.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Maybe we should get you home.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, hang on, hang on, hang on. Sheldon, what would it take for you to go into that liquor store, buy a bottle of hooch, take me across the street to that motel, and have your way with me?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, Sheldon, what would it take?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m begging both of you, please, let’s go.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay. Come on. Upsy-daisy.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Whee! Ooh, finally someone found second base.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So, Sheldon, tell us about your trip. Where’d you go?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Where didn’t I go? I went to New York, Chicago, Atlanta, Denver, Seattle.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: How were they?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, I have no idea. I never left the train station.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hang on. You travelled across the entire country and never left a train station?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Why would I? That’s where all the cool trains are.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, so you never went outside?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Or had a single piece of fruit.

turns.speaker: skype)
turns.transcript: Hello, Sheldon. What a pleasant surprise. How are you?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Honestly, I’ve been better. Do you have time? Leonard says you’re very busy these days.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Oh, I just say that because he prattles. What’s going on?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, our friend Raj moved into my old room, and it’s brought up a lot of negative feelings for me.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Mm. Well, what do you think the loss of your room represents?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Beverley, you know I hold you in high esteem. Can we skip the part where you pretend not to know the answer, and get to the part where you tell me the answer?

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Very well, but, uh, if you don’t mind, I’d still like to pause for effect. Now, you’ve recently moved in with Dr. Fowler, yes?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I have.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Clearly, your old room represents an escape hatch, and without it, you’re forced to confront the terrifying reality of being trapped in a relationship with Amy forever.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I hadn’t thought about that.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: And don’t start thinking about it now.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Hello, Amy. Your defensiveness may indicate similar insecurities about your relationship with Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: That’s not true.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: She said defensively.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: This isn’t about me and Sheldon. This is about Rajesh moving in with Leonard and Penny.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: Interesting. They’ve found a need to take yet another room mate. Seems they’re avoiding some harsh realities themselves.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I had no idea all our relationships were such a disaster. Boy, you’re good.

turns.speaker: Beverley
turns.transcript: That is the word on the street, dear.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: And Absolon hath kist hir nether yea, and Nicholas is scalded in the towte. This tale is doon, and God save al the rowte.”

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: What the hell was that?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Bernadette dared me to tell a dirty story. The Miller’s Tale by Chaucer is the dirtiest story I know. It would have been hidden in sock drawers if people in the 14th century had worn socks.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I thought it was pretty spicy. Especially the part where he kisses her nether yea.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You might not like it as much if you knew what nether yea meant. Hint, if one cares about hygiene, one ought not be kissing it.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Okay, my turn. Penny, truth or dare?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Truth.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Why are you still hanging out with Leonard so much even though you broke up with him?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh, that’s an excellent question. For two people who claim to be no longer pair-bonded, you spend an inordinate amount of time in each other’s company.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Dare.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I don’t believe the rules allow for an ex post facto option change.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, look, just because we’re not seeing each other anymore doesn’t mean we can’t be friends. I mean, Leonard’s a great guy.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Then, why did you terminate your relationship with him?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I don’t know. He got really serious, and I wasn’t ready for it.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Interesting. How will you react if, in the future, you become ready for it, and Leonard is unavailable, because another woman has realized that he is, to use your words, a great guy?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You can only ask one question.

turns.speaker: together
turns.transcript: That one.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You know what, I don’t want to play anymore.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Well, I’m not sure how this is scored, but I believe we may have won.

scene: The cafeteria. Sheldon is drawing on a napkin.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: What are you drawing over there?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s a hypothetical containment field for a Frisbee-sized wormhole that could serve as a portal to a parallel universe.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Oh, you silly doodlebug.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You know, a lot of scientists believe that making contact with other life-forms would probably not end well for us.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s a Frisbee-sized wormhole, Leonard. You can block it with a Frisbee. Calm down. (Hands Howard the napkin)

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Do you expect me to build this?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I expect you to wipe the pudding off your chin. Gentlemen.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Have you guys ever noticed that Sheldon always disappears every day at two forty-five?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Really?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: He probably just goes to the bathroom.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Actually, no, he goes to the bathroom at eight a.m. with optional follow-ups at one forty-five and seven ten high-fibre Fridays.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It’s sad that you know that.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, that’s just the tip of the sadness iceberg.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I’m looking at his public calendar. Two forty-five to three-oh-five, nothing. Yesterday, two forty-five to three-oh-five, nothing, last week, nothing, last month, nothing. He never has anything booked during that time.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Twenty minutes a day, completely unaccounted for.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: We should figure out where he goes.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Ooh, this is exciting. Like one of my classic murder mystery dinner parties.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Right, the case of who murdered three Saturday nights of my life?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Colonel Koothrapali in the kitchen with the olive spread.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It was tapenade and you guys suck.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: For Howie’s occupation, should I include that he was an astronaut?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Well, he mentioned it in his mother’s eulogy, so why not?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I can’t believe you have to fill out a preschool application for an infant.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Uh, the one at Caltech has a crazy wait list. I warned you, a lot of people apply when they’re still pregnant.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Well, I didn’t. I also skipped a birthing class to see Zootopia so back off.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Whoa. Just trying to help.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Sorry. Howie’s back at work and there’s just so much going on.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Is there anything we can do?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Sure. Open up a college fund, shop for life insurance, and in the laundry room, there’s a mountain of dirty laundry. Wash it or burn in, your choice. Ugh, be right back.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: No, no. I will take care of it.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Oh, thank you.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: While I’m gone, you can think about how mean you were to me.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right, you know what you need? A night away from all of this. You know, where you can just kind of relax and, I’m just gonna turn this off. Much better. Seriously, let’s plan a night, you know, give you a break. We could go dancing.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: That sounds really nice.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Oh. All this week, the Early Music Society of Pasadena is doing a joint concert with the San Gabriel Renaissance Choir.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, that’s the one to beat.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Good luck. People have been saying that for 600 years.

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: Where, where, where are we?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: This is the swampland of Dagobah. It’s where Luke was trained in the ways of the Jedi.

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: Oh. Too bad. I thought it was Florida.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: When Obi-Wan came to Luke on this very spot, he gave him all sorts of helpful advice. So, um, what do you got for me?

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: Um, always, get, get a prenup.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s it? I thought there’d be more of a reason why you’re here.

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: Well, why, why do you think I’m here?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I suppose it has something to do with your recent passing.

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: Is, is this the, the first time you’ve lost, you know, someone close to you?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, no. No. I’ve already had to say good-bye to 11 Dr. Whos.

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: Yeah, I’ve, I’ve outlived a few of my doctors, too.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Of course, my grandfather died when I was five. My father died when I was 14.

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: I’m, I’m sorry about that.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And now you’re gone, too. It’s like all the men I’ve looked up to have gone away.

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: Well, you know, it’s, it’s okay to, to be sad about them. Just, just make sure, you know, you appreciate those who, who are still there for you.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: But I do appreciate them.

turns.speaker: Arthur
turns.transcript: Well, then, what am I doing in a swamp dressed like Friar Tuck? Appreciate them, Sheldon. (Sheldon is woken up by a knocking on his bedroom door.)

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey, buddy. Heard you’re having a rough day. You all right?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m okay. How was the funeral?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: It was nice, you know. A lot of people showed up, told some great stories about him. Did you know that Arthur’s son is a high school sci…? (Sheldon hugs him) Hey, the guys are about to start Jedi. You want to go watch?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I do. After I make them go back and watch one through five first.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, that, that’ll take us all night.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That’s true. Oh, it’s a good thing I had a nap.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right, this is making me crazy. Somebody’s got to go over there.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You got feet and legs, you do it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Will you go with me?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: To do what? Shake a can of nickels at them?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: We’re being ridiculous. There’s no way a woman that attractive is trying to seduce Sheldon Cooper.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You done trying to make yourself feel better?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: No. I haven’t played the race card yet.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hey, I hate to break up the party, but Amy says I’m tired and have to go to bed.

turns.speaker: Ramona
turns.transcript: It was nice seeing everybody. Thank you for dinner.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Sure.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Our pleasure.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Whatever.

turns.speaker: Ramona
turns.transcript: Walk me to my car?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Of course.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: We’ll all go.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Excuse me.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Pardon. I just need to., yeah.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: That was fun. It was like Mario Kart.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I wish my mom was here. We could all hang out in her shadow.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Wool pants in the desert. I feel like I’ve got poached testicles.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, you poor thing, you’re sweating. That’s so much worse than having your car stolen.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Insurance is gonna buy you a new car. It’s not gonna de-funk my junk.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Gentlemen, a little less bellyaching. We’re Starfleet officers and a member of the Borg Collective.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Please, Sheldon, I am so not in the mood.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, all our lives we have dreamed of finding ourselves inside one of the fantasy worlds we love. And look at us. At this moment, we are, in fact, a Star Trek landing party stranded in an alien and unforgiving environment, relying only on our wits, our fortitude and our moxie. As long as we have those things, nothing can stop…

turns.speaker: Sheldon)
turns.transcript: Nerds!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I hate this planet.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Now, I assume we use this same wax later on to neaten up each other’s bikini regions.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah, my bikini region is fine.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Who’s shocked? I’m not. So, Bernadette, how’s the wedding planning going? And I’m not asking as a prospective bridesmaid. Pick me! Pick me!

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: We went cake-tasting yesterday. Raj came along. He cried and ate half the samples.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, the poor guy’s so lonely. We should set him up with someone.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: You know, I met a really cute girl at work. She’s married to a guy in one of our drug trials.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Well, hello? She’s married.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah, but her husband is in serious congestive heart failure, and a little birdie told me he’s in the placebo group.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, so future grief-stricken widow is the one to beat.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey, do me a favour and take table seven.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: You mean the one with my one hundred and eighteen-pound rock-hard stud of a fiancé who’s prone to canker sores and pinkeye?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Nah, I prefer to look at it as the one with my ex-boyfriend and his gorgeous, successful and sophisticated girlfriend, who makes me feel like a toothless Okie.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Do you want me to spill hot soup on her?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, please, you’re not that kind of person.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I know. But if she orders something low-fat I’ll totally give her the full-fat version.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Uh, that’s my water.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: My water. You’re drinking it.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Dear Lord! Have you been drinking it?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yes. It’s my water.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well, that’s it then. I’m dead.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Here we go.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I’m sorry, do I really need to connect the dots for you? The backwash into this glass is every pathogen that calls your mouth home, sweet home. Not to mention the visitors who arrive on the dancing tongue of your subtropical girlfriend.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hey! That’s my sister and my country you’re talking about. Leonard may have defiled one, but I won’t have you talking smack about the other.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: You guys ready to order?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes, I’d like a seven-day course of penicillin, some, uh, syrup of ipecac, to induce vomiting, and a mint.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I don’t understand.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: He drank from Leonard’s glass.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: He drank from Leonard’s glass. Words they’ll be carving into my tombstone.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: That’s actually my napkin.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, this is a nightmare!

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: To the bar, to sterilize my mouth with alcohol. Gang way! Dead man walking!

scene: The apartment. Raj is talking to his parents on the webcam.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: What are we supposed to say to Lalita’s parents?

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: I play golf with her father, I won’t be able to look at him.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Maybe you should keep your eye on the ball, Papa.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Oh, now you’re a funny man? This is not funny, Mr Funny Man.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Doctor and Mrs Koothrappali, in all fairness, it wasn’t entirely Raj’s fault.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: This is a family matter Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, I’m Leonard.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Oh, sorry, you all look alike to us.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: But he’s right, Papa, listen to him. (Sheldon enters) You! You are the one who ruined everything!

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Who is it? We can’t see.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Turn us, turn us.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Go ahead, tell my parents why they won’t have any grandchildren.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: How would I know, do you have a low sperm count?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: This has nothing to do with my sperm count.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: You are wearing the boxers that we sent you, aren’t you Rajesh.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Yes Mommy.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Because you know what happens to the samosas when you wear the tidy whities.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Can we please stop talking about my testicles? Sheldon, tell them what you did.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: What did I do?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You left with his date. Friends don’t do that to each other.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh. Alright, noted. Sorry.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Sorry? That’s all you can say is sorry?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Take it, Raj. It’s more than I’ve ever gotten.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And may I point out she wouldn’t have asked me to go with her if you hadn’t been drunk and boring.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Drunk?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: And boring, her words.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: I knew it, he moves to America and becomes an alcoholic.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I’m not an alcoholic.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Then why were you drunk?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: It was just this one time, Papa, I swear.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Are you in denial? Do we have to come over and do an intervention?

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Don’t embarrass him in front of his friends.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Alright. Carry us outside, we want to talk to you in private.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: But Papa, please….

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Now, Rajesh.

turns.speaker: Sheldon)
turns.transcript: I have to go.

turns.speaker: Koothrappali
turns.transcript: Now listen to me….

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Please wait until I get into the hall.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Okay, well, good night.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hold on. What happened with you and Lalita?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: We ate. She lectured me on the link between gum disease and heart attacks, nothing I didn’t already know, and I came home.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So you’re not going to see her again?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Why would I see her again? I already have a dentist. (Exits)

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I wonder who’s going to tell his parents they’re not having grandchildren.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: How’d it go with Leonard?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I don’t think he’ll be making that mistake again.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Good.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: So, I know this goes without saying, but if either of you tell Leonard you helped me rewrite this paper, I will beat you both with a bag of oranges.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Understood.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Got it.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Now, ladies, we got a B-minus on this paper. I think if we put our heads together, on the next one we could get an A.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Uh, but we got you a B-minus on purpose to make it believable.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Believable? You saying I’m not smart?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: No, no!

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: You’re smart.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: That’s better.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I feel like I’m in high school again.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah, doing the prom queen’s homework so she’ll like us.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I know. It’s finally working.

turns.speaker: Dan
turns.transcript: Penny. Oh, my rookie of the year.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, Dan. My boss who didn’t want to hire me and now’s a little hug machine.

turns.speaker: Dan
turns.transcript: Oh, look at you. Brand-new and already the third best sales rep.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Aw.

turns.speaker: Dan
turns.transcript: Yes. Why don’t you come over to my table.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I’ll be right there. Bernadette’s just parking the car.

turns.speaker: Dan
turns.transcript: Oh, good. Bernadette. Cute, sweet, vicious little Bernadette.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Come on. She’s not that bad.

turns.speaker: Dan
turns.transcript: Oh, yeah? At the company picnic she yelled at me and my grandson for losing the three-legged race. I mean, he still calls her that mean kid with the big boobies.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: I know she can be a little intense, but, I swear, she is so sweet once you get past all the…

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Hey, what are you talking about?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh. We were just talking about how much we love working with you. Isn’t that right? Dan?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Housekeeping.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: We had a complaint about somebody pooping on a party in there.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: It was us the whole time.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Why’d you tell her? It was working.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Was it working?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Oh, I’m so sorry.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: You guys look like you’re having fun.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: We’re having the best time.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Guess who won a hundred dollars playing craps.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: That’s a dollar.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Then guess who wildly overtipped a cocktail waitress.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Hey, Penny, hey, let’s go. We found a place that has Australian male strippers.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: We want to see if they twirl their junk in the other direction.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: That sounds so great. But I have a little more studying to do.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Can you believe this nerd?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Come on, do you want to sit here being a loser, or do you want to watch me climb into an Australian man’s G-string like a baby kangaroo?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: All right, guys, look, I would love to go out, but I’ve got to get this done, okay? So have fun at the club. And if you get in trouble, find a policeman. And if he’s taking off his pants, he is not a real policeman.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Okay, okay, this is obviously very important to her. Let’s just, we’ll help her study so she can get done quicker. Here, here, I’m gonna quiz you. I’m gonna quiz you. I got your notes. I got your notes. I got your notes. If you want these, they’re gonna be at the strip club.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Aren’t you gonna chase her?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: To the walk-in closet? Sure.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: All right, Raj has played his phantom warlord card, and I am going to back him up with my strangling vines. Choke on that, sucka.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Okay, well, then I’ll just cut your vines with my ruby sword. That’s right, I did it. I cut ’em.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Um, I have a question.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Warlord beats troll, troll beats elf, elf beats water sprite, and basically everything beats enchanted bunny.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Unless you have the carrot power.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, I’ve got another question. When does this get fun?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Are we going to talk or are we going to play Mystic Warlords of Ka-ah?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Just play a potion card.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Which one?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It doesn’t matter. You can’t possibly win.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon, don’t ruin the game.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: How could he ruin the game?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Given the cards that have already been played, Penny can only be holding necromancer potions, which are only effective against wraiths and day-walkers, and there are no more of either left to be drawn. The cards remaining in the undrawn stack are four fire weapons, a troll, two ogres and the jewel of Osiris.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: See? Ruined.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Sheldon, that is incredible.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: From your vantage point, it certainly must seem so.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Sheldon has kind of a photographic memory.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Photographic is a misnomer. I have an eidetic memory, as I’ve told you many times. Most recently last year during lunch on the afternoon of may seventh. You had turkey and complained it was dry.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, I guess game’s over.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Really? Oh, great. I mean, aw. Okay, I gotta go.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Why?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Because the last me I didn’t go, I ended up playing Mystic Warlords of Ka.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Not Ka. Ka-ah.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Ba-eye.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: See ya. Still can’t believe she’s going out with me.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Nobody can.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That reminds me, I have a bone to pick with you.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: What?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You and I made a pact that if either of us ever got a hot girlfriend, that person would have his girlfriend hook the other guy up with one of her girlfriends.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Yeah, I don’t remember that.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: June 30th, 2004. Opening day of Spider-man 2 at the AMC Pasadena. They only had red icees, no blue.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, yeah.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: So you’ve been with Penny for like a month and a half now. Where’s my shorty, Morty?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Howard, you can’t hold me to that.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Why not?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Because when I made that agreement, I didn’t think I’d ever have a hot girlfriend. And I was positive you never would.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hey, how come I wasn’t part of this deal?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: You had left the refreshment stand in order to indulge in your customary preemptive pre-show urination.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, so that’s how it works? I have a teeny bladder and now I don’t get a hot girlfriend?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, Raj, that’s how it works.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Damn.

scene: The apartment. Sheldon is listening to Darlin’

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I wonder why it was this particular song that was stuck in my head.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: I don’t know. It’s pretty catchy.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Do you even like the Beach Boys?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: They have beach right in the name. What do you think?

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Well, now that you can focus again, what do you say we get back to surface tension of domain walls?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Of course. I’m already seeing a more efficient way of taming the ultravi… I know why the song was in my head.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Why?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s about Amy.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, look, I know Amy’s like an old lady, but she’s not old enough to have a song from the sixties written about her.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: It’s about how she made my life better. Consider the lyrics. I was living like half a man. Then I couldn’t love, but now I can. More soul than I ever had. I love the way you soften my life.”

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: She did soften your life, didn’t she?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yes. She’s like the dryer sheets of my heart. I have to go.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Aw. Am I like the dryer sheets of your heart?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Better. You’re the lint trap of my love.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Aw.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: Howard! Bernadette’s… Oh, she slipped right by me.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Here’s your vest back.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You should keep it. You could wear it again sometime.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Where?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I don’t know, hunting?

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: Don’t forget to talk to her about this mishegas where I don’t get grandkids!

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Don’t worry, Ma. I will, as soon as I can figure out a way to bring up such a sensitive issue!

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I guess you talked to your mom, huh?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I was upset. My mom can be a pretty good shoulder to cry on, if the smell of Bengay doesn’t burn your eyes.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Look, it’s obvious having kids is really important to you, and I think I came up with a solution.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Really? That’s great. What?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Well, seeing as how I make way more money than you anyway, what if I work and you stay home with the kids?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Me?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yeah. You know, you’ll watch Barney and pull Cheerios out of their noses and go on play dates, and I’ll work and have conversations with people my own age and enjoy my life.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Yay, so we’re good.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Yeah, we’re good.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: You know, I don’t know if this counted as a fight, but how about some make-up sex?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I would love that. But what is that behind your ear? Oh, look, it’s a condom.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Can’t believe Bert has a girlfriend and I don’t.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I thought you were taking a break from women to focus on your career.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, grow up.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Don’t you have any friends he can date?

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Hey, I already set up Howard and Bernadette. It’s your turn to ruin some poor girl’s life.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh, hey, guys. Come in.

turns.speaker: Bert
turns.transcript: Thanks. Everyone, this is Rebecca.

turns.speaker: Rebecca
turns.transcript: Hi.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Hey.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: She’s younger and far more attractive than he is. They’re copying you two.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: This food is amazing.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Mm, and not a vegetable in sight.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That’s not true. We’ve got tomatoes right here.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: All these bright people sitting around a table by candlelight. Feels like we could be an 18th century French salon.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Indeed. Penny, a salon is a gathering where intellectuals entertained each other with sparkling conversations about issues of the day.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Oh, so it’s like The View.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon, The View is a daytime talk show hosted by women.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, I’m aware. It features Whoopi Goldberg. She played Guinan on Star Trek: Next Gen. Penny, Next Gen refers to Star Trek…

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Shut up.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: I would like to propose a salon topic.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Ooh, please do, Rajesh.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: The lead in The Hunger Games is a woman. Marvel has made Tor a female.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Wait, who’s Tor?

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: You know, Tor, the God of Tunder. As I was saying, is this a sign that our society is approaching gender equality?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Certainly a lot more women are reading comic books now.

turns.speaker: Stuart
turns.transcript: It’s true. At the store, I had to put a seat on the toilet.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: We won’t know if there’s equality until female Thor has a baby and the Avengers are cool with her pumping breast milk at work.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: I wonder if only a baby who is worthy can suckle at the bosom of Thor.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Okay, new salon topic. Salons, dumb thing from a long time ago or interesting thing made dumb by talking about superheroes? Discuss.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I don’t believe it matters what the topic is. What’s crucial for a salon is that we conduct the discussion in an elevated and insightful way. It’s all about the execution.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Of course you’d focus on that rather than the inspiration. Uh, new salon topic. What’s more important, an idea or its execution?

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Oh, that’s fine.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yeah, good for you, Leonard. That’s a lovely little notion. Kind of like, I wish I could talk to my uncle in Chicago. Yeah, now stand back while I invent the telephone. Hello? Oh, hold on. Leonard, it’s your uncle. He says you just got burned.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: Sheldon.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Guys.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: No, it’s okay. We’re all adults trying to have an intelligent discussion. At least I am. Howard, what do you think?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Well, I guess, as an engineer, I lean towards execution. I spend my days trying to take ideas and make them real.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Well said, old chap. I thought eloquence had died, here it stands before us. Starting today, it’ll go Gettysburg Address, I have a dream, and what he just said.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Oh, now he’s a genius? All you ever do is make fun of him and engineering.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, please. His mother just died.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You’re being ridiculous.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Yeah, so are you.

turns.speaker: Penny
turns.transcript: Guys, if I wanted to hear people be bitchy, I’d go to my real salon.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Leonard, lots of people could’ve had that idea, but very few people could’ve worked out the math the way I did.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: Lots of people also didn’t have that idea, like everyone in the entire world except for me.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Oh, well, apparently Leonard thinks he’s better than everyone in the whole world, including those fighting for our freedom. Yeah, well, I don’t know about you, but I support our boys overseas.

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: And girls.

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: Hey, you already ruined Thor, give it a rest.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: So I’m just supposed to be okay with you hogging all the credit?

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: I didn’t hog anything. Unlike you and that weird lasagna with raisins in it.

turns.speaker: Leonard
turns.transcript: You want some of this? I’ll give you some.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: Hey. Sheldon, Leonard, living room, right now!

turns.speaker: Sheldon
turns.transcript: She said my name first, that must kill you.

turns.speaker: (off)
turns.transcript: I don’t know what you think you’re doing, but this is a very difficult time for my husband. We’re eating the last food his mother ever made, and you were gonna throw it at each other like children? Whatever it is you’re fighting about, put it aside, go back in there and be a good friend to Howard or there’s no dessert for either of you. Look at me when I’m talking to you. And don’t think…

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: You guys ever notice sometimes Bernadette sounds like my mom?

turns.speaker: Amy
turns.transcript: I don’t hear it.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: No, not at all.

turns.speaker: phone)
turns.transcript: Okay. Thanks, daddy. He said the only way to really fix an old floor like that is to tear it up and replace the whole thing.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: That sounds expensive.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Hang on. No offence to her father, but he’s not an MIT trained engineer. Thinking and building is what you do.

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: MIT’s motto is mind and hand, which just so happens was also my motto as a lonely teenager.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Oh come on, we just need to be more creative. What if you didn’t step on the floor at all? Like, what if you swung on a rope from the ceiling?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Raj
turns.transcript: Okay, um, okay, what if you rig up a pulley system and move yourself across the room in a harness?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: No.

turns.speaker: Bernadette
turns.transcript: I have one. What if you got a giant slingshot and flung yourself into the wall?

turns.speaker: Howard
turns.transcript: Is that supposed to be funny?

turns.speaker: Raj
